div.head: The Desolate Valley. A South-African Scene. By Thomas Pringle
div.p: [The result of the Caffer war of 1819-20 ^between the Colonial Government of the Cape and & the Caffer tribes was the annexation to the Colony of a large track of the Amakosa country, extending to about two millions of acres. This was affected by a compulsory convention with the native chiefs (our ally Gaika included), who, with their followers, were then dislodged and expelled beyond the Keisi and Chumi rivers. The whole of the evacuated territory, under the appellation of the Neutral Ground, remained unoccupied for several years, and a large portion of it remains so still. I made an excursion through part of it, from the Winterberg mountain down the river Koonap, in 1822, in company with Captain (now Colonel) C. R. Fox and some other officers, and again, in 1825, in another direction. The aspect of the country, though wild, was beautiful and impossible; it was finely diversified with lofty mountains and winding glens, with picturesque rocks and forests, open upland pastures, and level savannas along the rivers, sprinkled with mimosa-trees: and herds of wild animals, quaggas, elands, hartebeests, gnuos, koodoos, with many varieties of the smaller antelopes, were scattered over the verdant pastures; while troops of elephants were browsing undisturbed among the wooded kloofs and jungles of evergreens. But the remains of Caffer hamlets, scattered through every grassy nook and dell, and now long deserted and fast crumbling to decay, excited reflections of no gratifying character, and occasionally increased, even to a painful degree, the feeling of melancholy lonesomeness which a country void of human inhabitants never fails to inspire. Before the Caffers ^and Ghonaquas were expelled from this territory, a few of them had acquired some knowledge of Christianity, partly from the instructions of that singular but most meritorious man Dr. Vanderkemp, and more especially from the missionary Williams, who resided about two years among them at the Kat River, previous to his death in 1818. The following stanzas are an attempt to give a sketch of a remote vale in this wild country, after the first missionary station had been left desolate, & previous to its occupation by the Emancipated Hottentots & their Christian Pastors in 1829.]

lg.l: Far up among the forest-belted mountains,
Where Winterberg, stern giant old & grey,
Looks down the subject dells, whose gleaming fountains
To Wizard Kat their virgin tribute pay,
A valley opens to the moontide ray,
With green Savannahs shelving to the brim
Of the young River, sweeping on his way
To where Umtoka hies to meet with him,
Like a blue serpent gliding through the acacias dim.

lg.label: II.
lg.l: Round this secluded region circling rise
A billowy waste of mountains, wild and wide;
Upon whose grapy slopes the pilgrine spies
The gnu and quagga by the greenwood side,
Shaking their shaggy manes in tameless pride;
Or troop of elands near some sedgy forest;
Or koodoo fawns, that from the ^thicket bathes[?] glide
To seek their dam beneath the misty mount;
With roebucks, harts, gazelles, more than the eye may count.

lg.label: III.
lg.l: And, as we journeyed up the ^tangled pathless glen,
Flanked by romantic hills on either hand,
The bush-buck oft would bound away -- and then,
Beside the copsewood'willows' (BiC)., backward gazing, stand.
And where old forests darken all the land,
From rocky Katberg to the river's brink,
The buffalo would start upon the strand
Where, 'midst palmetto reeds'flags' (BiC)., he stooped to drink,
And, crashing through the brakes, to the deep jungle shrink.

lg.label: IV.
lg.l: Then, couched at night in hunter's leafy ^wattled shieling,
How wildly beautiful it was to hear
The elephant his shrill reveill√© pealing,
Like some far signal-trumpet on the ear:
While the broad midnight moon was shining clear,
How fearful to look forth upon the woods,
And see those stately forest-kings appear,
Emerging from their mountain solitudes --
As if that trump had woke Earth's old gigantic broods!

lg.label: V.
lg.l: Such was the fair but melancholy scene
Which 'midst that lonely wilderness 'we' (BiC).the pilgrim found,
With scarce a trace to tell where man had been,
Save the old Caffer hamlets cabins crumbling round.
Yet this lone'wild' (BiC). region glen (Sicana's ancient ground)
To Nature's savage herds'tribes' (BiC). abandoned long,
Had heard, erewhile, the Gospel's joyful sound,
And low of herds mixed with the Sabbath song.
But all is silent nowThis is a full stop in the published version.: the' Oppressor's hand was strong!

lg.label: VI.
lg.l: Now the gay loxia hangs her pensile nest
From the wild-olive, bending o'er the rock,
Beneath whose shadow, in grave mantle drest,
The meek-eyed Pastor taught his native swarthy flock.
A roofless ruin, marked'scathed' (BiC). by flame & smoke,
Tells where the decent Mission-chapel stood:
While the baboon & wild satyr ^with jabbering cry doth mock
The pilgrim, pausing, in his pensive mood,
To ask -- "Why is it thus? Shall evil baffle good?"

lg.label: VII.
lg.l: Yes -- for a season Satan shall ^may prevail,
And hold, as if secure, his dark domain;
The prayers of righteous men shall ^may seem to fail,
And Heaven's Glad Tidings be proclaimed in vain. --
But wait in faith: ere long shall spring again
The seed that seemed to perish in the ground;
And, fertilized by Zion's latter rain,
The long-parched lands shall laugh, with harvests crowned,
And through those silent wastes Jehovah's praise resound.

lg.label: VIII.
lg.l: Look round that Valley'Vale' (BiC).: where'behold' (BiC). the unburied bones
Of Afric's ^Ghona's children whiten'withering' (BiC) in the blast --: (BiC).
Can the sad wind that through the forest moans
To these breathe back the spirit that hath passed?
Thus ^So, in the dust of d Vale of Desolation vast,
In moral death dark Afric's myriads lie:
But the appointed day shall dawn at last,
When, breathed on by the Spirit from on High,
The dry bones shall awake, and shout -- "Our God is nigh!"
